symptoms: Circular or slightly elliptical pustules on leaves
Orange to orange-brown urediospores in pustules
Pustules primarily on upper surfaces of leaves and leaf sheaths
Occasional infection on neck and awns
Pustules usually do not coalesce

conditions.survival: Survive on stubbles and volunteer crops

cultural: Use resistant varieties: Lerma Rojo, Safed Lerma, Sonalika, Chotil

symptoms: Dark reddish-brown pustules on both sides of leaves, stems, and spikes
Pustules usually separate and scattered, coalescing under heavy infection
Flecks appear before pustule formation
Surface tissues appear rough to touch before spore masses break through
Ragged and torn appearance of tissues as spores break through epidermis

conditions.survival: Survive on stubbles and volunteer crops

symptoms: Yellow to orange-yellow urediospores in narrow stripes on leaves
Pustules form narrow stripes along leaf veins
Can appear on leaf sheaths, necks, and glumes
Characteristic yellow striping pattern distinguishes from other rusts

conditions.survival: Survive on stubbles and volunteer crops

cultural: Use resistant varieties: Lerma Rojo, Safed Lerma, Sonalika, Chotil

symptoms: Entire inflorescence replaced by masses of black smut spores except rachis
Black teliospores blown away by wind leaving bare rachis
Only remnants of floral structures remain after spore dispersal

conditions.spread: Seed-borne; spores infect flowers during anthesis

region: All wheat growing areas of India

symptoms: Attacks at all growth stages from seedling to ear heading
Small bluish-green flecks on leaves that enlarge to spindle-shaped spots with grey centre and dark brown margin (Leaf Blast)
Spots coalesce causing large areas to dry and wither
Black lesions on nodes causing nodal blast; plant parts above infection die
Grayish-brown lesions on neck causing panicle to fall over (Neck Blast)
No grain formed if neck infection occurs before milky stage

cultural: Use resistant varieties: Penna, Pinakini, Tikkana, Sreeranga, IR-64, Jaya, IR-36, MTU 9992, MTU 1005, MTU 7414
Burning of straw and stubbles after harvest

symptoms: Seedling wilt (kresek): 1-3 weeks after transplanting, leaves wilt and turn grayish-green to yellow, entire plant wilts
Water-soaked to yellowish stripes on leaf blades starting at leaf tips with wavy margin
Undulated yellowish-white or golden yellow marginal necrosis
Bacterial ooze (milky/opaque dewdrop) on young lesions early morning
Severely infected leaves dry quickly
Yield loss up to 60%

conditions.weather: Warm temperature 25-30°C, high humidity, rain, deep water
conditions.spread: Irrigation water, rain, trimming tools during transplanting

preventive: Seed treatment with bleaching powder (100g/l) and zinc sulphate (2%)
Seed soaking 8 hours in Agrimycin (0.025%) followed by hot water at 52-54°C for 30 min
Spray fresh cowdung extract (20g cowdung in 1 litre water)
cultural: Grow tolerant varieties: IR 20, IR 72, PONMANI, TKM 6, Swarna, Ajaya, Deepti, MTU-9992
chemical: Spray Streptomycin sulphate + Tetracycline 300g + Copper oxychloride 1.25kg/ha
Foliar spray with copper fungicides alternated with Streptocyclin (250 ppm)

region: All rice growing states of India

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Organic Farming Disease Management
symptoms: Occurs in nursery and main crop
Isolated brown round to oval spots resembling sesame seeds (0.5-2.0mm breadth)
Spots coalesce to form large patches causing blight of seedlings
Black or brown spots on glumes covered by olivaceous velvety growth
Infection on panicle neck with brown color
50% yield reduction in severe cases

conditions.predisposing: Nutrient deficient soils, high temperature and humidity

chemical: Hot water seed treatment at 53-54°C for 10-12 minutes

region: More severe in Bengal, Odisha, AP

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Organic Farming Disease Management
pathogen: Rice Tungro Virus (RTV) - bacilliform and spherical viruses
symptoms: Stunting and reduced tillering
Leaves become yellow or orange-yellow, may have rust-colored spots
Discoloration begins from leaf tip extending down the blade
Delayed flowering; panicles small and not completely exserted
Most panicles sterile or with partially filled grains

conditions.season: Any time; epidemics during 1985-87 in Tamil Nadu

cultural: Grow tolerant varieties: MTU 9992, MTU 1002, MTU 1003, MTU 1005, Surekha, Vikramarya, Bharani, IR 36
In epidemic areas follow rotation with pulses or oilseeds
chemical: Control green leafhopper vector with systemic insecticides

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Crop Protection Horticultural Crops
symptoms: Water-soaked spots on leaves increasing in size turning purple-brown and finally black
White growth develops on underside of leaves
Spreads to petioles, rachis and stems; frequently develops at nodes
Stem breaks at infected nodes and plant topples over
Purplish-brown spots on tubers spreading to entire surface
Rusty brown necrosis spreading from surface to center when tuber is cut

conditions.favoring: Cloudiness before rainfall, rainfall at least 0.1mm

cultural: Resistant varieties: Kufri Naveen, Kufri Jeevan, Kufri Alenkar, Kufri Khasi Garo, Kufri Moti
Destroy foliage few days before harvest
Avoid injuries at harvest; do not store visibly infected tubers
chemical: Protective spraying with Mancozeb or Zineb 0.2% to prevent tuber infection
Spray every 7-10 days under favorable conditions

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Crop Protection Horticultural Crops
symptoms: Brown circular spots with concentric rings (target board appearance) on older leaves
Yellowing around lesions
Lesions appear first on lower leaves and spread upward
Severe infection causes premature defoliation

conditions.weather: Warm days with high humidity followed by cool nights

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Crop Protection Horticultural Crops
symptoms: Sudden wilting of lower leaves that spreads upward
Internal browning of vascular ring in stem and tuber
Bacterial ooze from cut stem when placed in water
Tuber shows brown discoloration in vascular ring and may ooze slime

cultural: Crop rotation with non-solanaceous crops for 3-4 years
chemical: No effective chemical control; prevention is key

region: All potato growing areas, especially humid regions

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Organic Farming Disease Management
symptoms: Discolouration of young leaves; margins and tips wither and droop
Withering continues from tip to leaf base; plant dies within 4-8 days
Entire stem rots with central tissues becoming pithy
Reddened tissues throughout basal portion especially vascular bundles
Characteristic white patches interrupting reddened tissues (diagnostic)
Shrinkage of internodes; large cavities in center when split open
Leaves show dark red lesions in mid-rib turning blood-red with dark margins

conditions.spread: Infected setts, water flow from affected fields
conditions.season: Monsoon period enables faster disease spread

cultural: Cultivate only resistant varieties: Co 8021, Co 85019, Co 86010, Co 86032, Co 86249, Co 93009, Co 99004, Co 99006 (Tropical); Bo 91, Co 89003, Co 98015, Co 99015 (Subtropical)
Phytosanitation and domestic quarantine to prevent movement of setts from endemic areas
Clear fields of excessive trash and ensure efficient drainage
chemical: Hot water treatment of setts at 52°C for 30 minutes before planting

region: All sugarcane growing areas of India
Particularly UP, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, AP
season: Year-round crop; disease more severe during monsoon

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Organic Farming Disease Management
symptoms: Symptoms appear only when plant has grown 4-5 months
Gradual withering of canes
Pith discolored purple or dirty red with longitudinal streaks
Leaves gradually turn yellow and dry up
Characteristic disagreeable odour from diseased canes
Cottony white mycelium visible in pith region

conditions.history: First reported 1913; severe damage in Deccan plateau 1965-1967

cultural: Select seed setts from disease-free areas
Avoid alkaline soils for crop growing
Use resistant varieties: Co-617 and B.P.-17 more resistant in wilt-sick soils

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Crop Protection Cash Crops
symptoms: Affected shoots produce a black whip-like structure at the growing point
Black smut sori emerge from the cane tip in a whip or sickle shape
Affected plants are stunted with thin canes
Multiple thin shoots arising from ratoon stumps

cultural: Hot water treatment of setts at 50°C for 2 hours
Remove and destroy affected plants immediately

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Organic Farming Disease Management
symptoms: Proliferation of vegetative buds from base of cane giving crowded bunch of tillers
Tillers bear pale yellow to completely chlorotic narrow leaves
Cane formation rarely takes place; if formed canes are thin with short internodes
Virus transmitted through infected setts and crop ratooning; aphids are vectors

conditions.hosts: Also infects jowar, Napier grass and Madras grass

cultural: Eradication of diseased parts as soon as symptoms noticed
Avoid selection of setts from diseased area
Pre-treat healthy setts with hot water at 52°C for 1 hour before planting
Treat with hot air at 54°C for 8 hours
chemical: Spray twice a month with aphidicides to control vector

source: TNAU Agritech Portal - Organic Farming Disease Management
symptoms: Affected plants are stunted; most severe in stubble and ratoon crops
Setts from diseased plants germinate poorly
Few shoots that emerge grow very slowly
No visible external symptoms other than stunting and reduced yield

conditions.spread: Mainly through planting material (infected setts) and cutting tools

cultural: Hot water treatment of setts at 50°C for 2 hours gives 100% control
Sterilize cutting tools between plants with disinfectant
